questions.question_text: What are two ways that dimensions and measures are different? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B. Measures are aggregated and dimensions are not
C. Dimensions affect the level of detail of a visualization and measures do not

Selected Answer: BC
BC is correct.

Selected Answer: BC
BC correct
BC is the answer

Selected Answer: BC
BC, 100%
BC Correct.

Selected Answer: BC
measures are aggregated (containting numbers) and dimensions can be used to filter

choices.B: Measures are aggregated and dimensions are not
choices.A: Dimensions can be used in calculated fields and measures cannot
choices.C: Dimensions affect the level of detail of a visualization and measures do not
choices.D: Measures can be used as filters and dimensions cannot

questions.question_text: At a minimum, what do you need to create a simple scatter plot?

choices.D: A dimension on Columns and a dimension on Rows
choices.C: A dimension on Columns and a measure on Rows
choices.B: A dimension on Detail and a measure on Columns
choices.A: A measure on Columns and a measure on Rows

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. A measure on Columns and a measure on Rows

Selected Answer: A
A correct tried
2 measures .. one each on a row and a column gives a scatterplot. A is the right answer

Selected Answer: A
A correct
A correct.

Selected Answer: A
A is the right answer. In Tableau you create a scatter plot by placing a measure in the columns shelf and another measure in the rows shelf.

I think the right answer is A. Scatter plots are created with two to four measures, and zero or more dimensions. The first two measures form the y-axis and x-axis; then the third and/or fourth measures as well as dimensions can be used to add context to the marks.
it's a

Selected Answer: A
"Appending" means to add to the end, and you do that with columns of data that have shared (or the same type of) values. That's not a join, but a union. If you combine columns where the tables have shared values, now that's a join. The answer is most definitely A.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: B
B. A way to combine table columns in relational databases by using shared values

Selected Answer: A
A JOIN is a means for combining columns from multiple tables by using values common to each
A JOIN is a means for combining columns from multiple tables by using values common to each

Selected Answer: B
B is right
B is the right answer
B is correct.

questions.question_text: Which statement accurately describes a join?

choices.D: A combination of rows appended from different tables that have the same column names
choices.A: A combination of columns appended from different tables that have similar values
choices.B: A way to combine table columns in relational databases by using shared values
choices.C: A way to combine multiple Tableau workbooks using similar data sources

questions.question_text: Which two filter modes can you use with continuous filters? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C. Range of Values
D. Special

Multiple/Single values are for Dimension, A,B not the answser
when you add filter for Measure
there are 4 modes: range of value, at least, at most, spcial

if choose for only one, C is the answer, at least and at most are also filter for 'range of value'

the 'special' mode is for Non-Null or Null Value, will filter/match multiple values
if choose for 2, C and D is the answer.

Selected Answer: CD
RANGE OF VALUES
AT LEAST
AT MOST
SPECIAL

Selected Answer: CD
Range of the value and special
Answer is CD. Range of values and Special
CD correct.
its cd
its ABC

Selected Answer: ABC
For 100%, ABC
ABC correct.
It's ABC

choices.A: Can have multiple source and target sheets

choices.B: Can be set to run on Hover. Select, or Menu
